videogameversion.155262: North American Game Boy Advance edition

120916.description:
From the back of North American GBA box

Who Ya Gonna Call?

In an attempt to take over the world, the newly liberated and powerful ectoplasmic forces, led by the half-human, half-demon Count Mercharior, have kidnapped two key members of the Extreme Ghostbusters team. Without wasting a second, Eduardo and Kylie jump into the famouse Ecto-1 ambulance and race off to the rescue... Play as Eduardo and Kylie as you uncover the clues to the kidnapping, confront the evil Count Mercharior and return your teammates, Roland and Garrett, to safety !

-The entire universe and charectors of the well-known animated series in a brand-new adventure!

-12 exciting platform levels through 4 gigantic worlds!

-4 exhilararting car races across the busy streets of New York City!

120917.name: Pac-Man World 3
120917.description:
Pac-Man World 3 is the third game in the Pac-Man World series and the only one in the trilogy that was not released in Japan. It also marks the 25th anniversary of the Pac-Man arcade game. This game features more fighting and more melee combat than the first two Pac-Man World games. It also features a speaking Pac-Man for the first time.

In a search for power, a short evil genius called Erwin has found a way to suck raw energy out of the world of the Ghosts (the Spectral Realm). He has created a syphon that can penetrate into the Spectral Realm. This is causing the Spectral Realm to collapse into the real world (Pac-Land), bringing about an environmental catastrophe. Meanwhile, Pac-Man is celebrating his 25th birthday with his family when he is teleported by Orson, a former nemesis of Pac-Man from the first Pac-Man World video game. Orson communicates to him and tells him about the Spectral Realm (after Pac-Man complains to Orson about messing up his party and throwing him into a trash pit). Pac-Man is attacked by fiery Spectral monsters of the orange, green, and purple varieties which have been driven mad by Erwin's hypnosis with Inky and Blinky have been kidnapped as part of Erwin's evil scheme, but Pinky and Clyde managed to escape. Now Pac-man must join forces with the ghosts, Orson, Pinky, and Clyde to stop Erwin before he destroys both the Real World and the Spectral Realm.

Cutscenes pop up throughout the game, and instead of having just subtitles, the characters speak as well. The subtitles are configurable in the game's settings.

Pac-Man retains his moves from the previous two Pac-Man World games, like the butt-bounce and the rev-roll, and he gets the ability to punch. Now, butt-bouncing three times in a row will create a shock-wave that will affect enemies circling in on Pac-Man. However, the shock-wave won't go out very far, so it's not very useful. Also, when Pac-Man rev-rolls, pressing the jump button will not make Pac-Man stop rev-rolling. He will jump as he's rolling instead.

Normal attacks don't work on Spectral monsters, but Pac-Man can eat a power pellet, turning the ghosts blue, just like the original.

There is a museum accessible by the main menu. where you can look at Pac-Man game history, and play Pac-Man itself. The game is a port of the original, and, unlike the previous Pac-Man World games, there is no border around the vertical game screen.

Source: Wikipedia, "Pac-Man World 3", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

120918.name: Pac-Man World Rally
120918.description:
Pac-Man World Rally, (known in Europe as Pac-Man Rally) is a kart racing game in the Pac-Man franchise.

The game has 15 race tracks and a battle mode similar to other kart racing games. In addition, there are four battle arenas for multiplayer action. You will also be able to collect power-ups to attack opponents or gain an edge in the race, as well as Pac-Man's signature fruit pickups, which in Pac-Man World Rally unlock secret shortcuts. There are 16 characters for the player to choose from.

Pac-Man World Rally contains gameplay that is standard to cart racing games. It also contains a 4-player multiplayer mode where you can access characters from both the Pac-Man world and many other Bandai Namco games. Pac-boxes are available on the track and allow the player the gift of one item. Pac-dots are also available on the racetrack. Each Pac-dot collected helps the player's meter go up. Once it is full, the player can press the specified button and turn into Pac-Man, and all the other players turn into blue(vulnerable) ghosts. If the Pac-Man eats any of the blue ghosts, the blue ghosts will stop for a while and get a major disadvantage on the track. This event only lasts eight seconds. A fruit activation button is on the racetrack. When the player runs over the button, fruit is scattered around the racetrack. When you run over the fruit, it allows the shortcut that corresponds with the fruit to become open for you.

Source: Wikipedia, "Pac-Man World Rally", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

120919.name: Sorcery (1984)
120919.description:
User Summary

The Necromancer has imprisoned eight of the Great Sorcerers and his minions roam the land. You're the last free Sorcerer, your goal is to free your colleagues from the Necromancer's jails before it's too late.

Sorcery is an arcade-adventure game. The player must explore the game world (40 screens) and collect items to destroy the many monsters, open locked doors and free the other sorcerers. Contact with a monster drains energy, which can be replenished, and the game has a time limit represented by a gradually disappearing grimoire.

The game was used extensively in Amstrad commercial as a demonstration of the CPC's graphic capabilities.

120921.name: Pipo Saru 2001
120921.description:
Pipo Saru 2001 has only been released in Japan. A demo was released through McDonald's named the "Happy Disc". The levels were slightly altered to contain Fries and Burgers as life's and the levels re-designed to contain McDonald's balloons and Signs. A North American version was planned with the working title Ape Escape 2001, but it was canceled.

Piposaru 2001's Gameplay differs from the original Ape Escape gameplay outline. The left analog stick on the DualShock controller is used to control Spike's movement, but unlike the original game, the right analog stick was unused and the Face buttons were used to attack. The goal of each level is to use a vacuum cleaner to remove a required amount of pants off of the apes and put them into an oversized washing machine, while preventing the monkeys from re-obtaining their shorts or attacking the player. While sucking the pant off a monkey, the monkey can be fired into other monkeys to knock them out. Bomb tokens can also be collected to attack monkeys and bosses. The graphics were slightly improved yet very similar to the original game, with the same symbols throughout the game (such as the stage cleared symbol). Also (like the first), it was made for a broader audience from ages 5 onwards, unlike Ape Escape 2 & Ape Escape 3 which was intended for younger audiences. Also, Piposaru 2001 was the first game in the series to feature no other enemies excluding the apes.

The storyline is a simpler compared to the original game. Specter has made all the monkeys' pants dirty and Spike/ Kakeru has to wash them. Although the storyline & controls were simple, the levels of the game were designed rather well. It also featured many more levels than the original game. It has 36 stages while the original had only 19. Each level is timed. The storyline changed and is a similar game style to Ape Escape Pumped & Primed. There are five stages to complete, and then a boss battle in each level. Much like Pumped and Primed's layout.

The game features fewer characters than the previous games.
Spike/Kakeru - The red haired protagonist of the first game who defeated Specter.
Natalie/Natsumi - The Professor's granddaughter that assists Spike on his journey.
Professor/Hakase- The Professor who invented the pipo helmet, warp/time machine, and other gadgets.
Specter - The evil monkey who has attempted world domination. His intelligence is increased by the pipo helmet.
Pipo Monkeys- The common monkeys of the game series.

Source: Wikipedia, "Pipo Saru 2001", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

120922.name: Wonderland
120922.description:
Two players play as the Red or White Queens of Wonderland.

Through playing cards as either events or as influence, players can spread their ifluence throughout a modular map of Wonderland in order to gain control of the magical world.

Players also can try to control the mysterious Alice and help woo her to their cause.

The Queen who can influence Wonderland the greatest wins.

120923.name: Tennis 3D
120923.description:
User Summary

A tennis simulation by French developer Loriciel.

The game can be played against the computer or a human opponent. Game options include choice of playing surface, number of sets and two different racket controls.

120924.description:
HUMANS HAVE A BRAIN, BUT ZOMBIES HAVE A HEART…

Night falls over the bleak Evans City Mall.
The dead are awaken and some lucky survivors trapped in the big building have to defend themselves from the Zombie Horde and find a way out.
The only chance is Old Pop’s Minivan. Too bad it can carry just one person.
To make things worse, there’s no fuel in the Minivan and the Keys are lost somewhere in one of the Shops. It will take both brawns and brains… It’s time to make some heads rolling, betray all the others and run away to safety!

Night falls over the happy looking Evans City Mall.
Just a few Humans are left roaming all sad and alone with nobody caring for them. No one willing to hug them, no one that loves them. They all roam around that old Minivan, that’s weird. And much too weird, they run away or try to hit us with heavy things instead of joining us in a big hug. They are confused by fear and loneliness, but the Horde will never stop loving! It will take some effort and a big heart but we will finally hug and cuddle them all to be happy ever after! Love will finally win over everything else!

Aim of the Game
Players in Hug Me all starts as humans. But life is hard in Evans City and during the game they can become Infected and later on Zombies.
If you are Human, you must escape the City Mall. To do so you must find the Fuel Tank first, then the Key (or the Spare Key) and take them to the Minivan.
If you are Infected, you must blow up the City Mall so that the Horde cannot spread outside. To do so you must find the Fuel Tank first than the Lighter and take them to the Boiler Room. If you are a Zombie you must hug all humans so that love wins over everything! Zombies win all together when there are no more humans in the game.
Zombie players must really hug Human players to validate the Hug, otherwise the contamination is void!

Quick Rules

Dawn: If you are a Zombie, draw a Zombie card, secretly choose one or more Room Cards and place your Zombie Character and the Zombie Card in one or more Rooms.

Day: According to turn Humans can move and take an action (or vice versa). They can choose one of these Actions: Stealing (Challenge another player to take an Item from him/her), Barricading (Block a Room so that for the rest of the Day and the next night nobody can move to or from that Room also getting a bonus to Zombie Assaults) Searching (Draw an Item from the Deck in the Room where your Character is).

Night: All Room Cards chosen by Zombie Players are revealed. If there are Humans in those Rooms, Humans face the Assault. If any Human survives, they draw one Zombie Card each and face the normal Assault for that turn.

If Humans lose an Assault, they try to Escape and if they fail they are Infected and from now on they roll the Zombie Die each turn. If they fail the roll, they become Zombies.

If an Infected becomes a Zombie, he/she removes his/her Keyholder from the game and starts playing as a Zombie from the next Dawn phase placing his/her Zombie Character and a Zombie Card secretly in one or more Rooms.

Humans win if, after finding the Fuel Tank and the Key, they get to the Minivan.
Infected win if, after finding the Fuel Tank and the Lighter, they get to the Boiler Room.
Zombies win if there are no more Humans in the game.
120924.name: Hug Me

120925.name: Pro Evolution Soccer

videogamehonor.29279: 2002 Golden Joystick Best Sports Game of the Year Winner

120925.description:
Pro Evolution Soccer (also known as World Soccer: Winning Eleven 5 in Japan and North America) is the first installment of Konami's Pro Evolution Soccer football video game series that was released on October 30, 2001 in Europe.

Player animations (compared to previous versions such as ISS2 Pro Evolution) have been improved. The stadiums and crowds have been reworked for added realism. Some components such as flares, stadium shadows and multi-tired stadiums made their first appearances in the series. The game includes FIFPro licenses for 53 National teams and 32 Club teams; including unlicensed names for six hidden teams and 33 hidden players.

Goalkeepers are much smarter, actually saving headers on occasion and not letting in quite as many howlers as past iterations in the series. In terms of shooting and passing, little seems to have changed. Lobbed shots can still be performed by either double-tapping shoot or pressing L1 in conjunction with the shoot button. Players run even more intelligently off the ball than before, and the ball itself seems to react more unpredictably than ever—rolling through players' legs, ricocheting off defenders, and even occasionally bouncing favorably (some would say luckily) for a player.

Scoring is no simple affair, requiring equal doses of strategy, planning, and skill. Charging blindly toward an opponent's goal area will usually result in the player being dispossessed. Intelligent passing, individual skill, and a little touch of magic are the ingredients for success, making the act of scoring a truly enjoyable moment instead of a routine formality. Blasting a 30-yard strike home is just as satisfying as a well-worked play, as are the many other methods of scoring, be they skilful runs through the midfield or fortunate deflections off a defender.

Source: Wikipedia, "Pro Evolution Soccer", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

120927.name: Pro Evolution Soccer 2

videogamehonor.29367: 2003 Golden Joystick PlayStation Game of the Year Nominee

120927.description:
Pro Evolution Soccer 2 (known as Winning Eleven 6 in Japan and World Soccer: Winning Eleven 6 in North America) is the second installment of Konami's Pro Evolution Soccer football video game series. It was the last game of the series released in Europe for PlayStation and unique in the series for Nintendo Gamecube release, only in Japan with the title "Winning Eleven 6 Final Evolution".

The gameplay is similar to the first Pro Evolution Soccer.

Source: Wikipedia, "Pro Evolution Soccer 2", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

120928.name: Pro Evolution Soccer 3

videogamehonor.29159: 2003 Golden Joystick Game of the Year Winner

120928.description:
Pro Evolution Soccer 3 (also known as Winning Eleven 7 in Japan and World Soccer Winning Eleven 7 in the US) is the third installment of Konami's Pro Evolution Soccer football video game series. It is also the first in the series to be released on PC. The cover features famed referee Pierluigi Collina.

This game came with:
New graphics engine.
Improved gameplay, control, ball physics, animation and AI.
New Shop mode, where points can be traded in for hidden items.
Master League expanded to four divisions, with tons of new players.

Source: Wikipedia, "Pro Evolution Soccer 3", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

120932.name: Puzzle Challenge: Crosswords and More
120932.description:
Puzzle Challenge: Crosswords and More is a video game that came out in 2006 for Playstation 2 and PSP. It has over 1,000 word and logic games. The puzzle games include crosswords, codebreakers, word searches (also mini and micro word searches), kriss kross (also mini kriss kross) and several others. As the player progresses, they can complete puzzles to unlock backdrops, audio tracks, and trophies.

This is the first Playstation 2 and PSP word puzzle game to come out in the United States. The Wii version was released in 2009.

Source: Wikipedia, "Puzzle Challenge: Crosswords and More", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

120933.name: The Cupcake Game
120933.description:
A children's game for 2-4 players. Each player chooses 1 of the 4 recipe cards that (s)he want to bake. Then it's a race to see who can "bake" their cupcakes the fastest! In order to bake their goodies, players must first collect all the ingredients on their recipe card. To get your ingredients, you must flick the spatula spinner and hope it lands where you want (and not the the rotten egg - lose a turn space!)

The game is designed to be a fun way to help kids learn about following multi-step instructions, patience, taking turns, and matching & categorization, as well learning about baking in general!

Plus, the game is made from 90% recycled materials and is printed with soy-based inks!

120935.name: Dun Darach
120935.description:
From Wikipedia: Dun Darach is an arcade adventure published in 1985 by Gargoyle Games. The game is a prequel to the 1984 game Tir Na Nog as the story takes place before that game, when Cuchulainn was still alive. The background history is based on Celtic folklore about the hero Cuchulainn, and his battles against the people of Connachta in ancient Ireland.

Dun Darach is an arcade adventure with interface and presentation nearly identical to Tir Na Nog or Marsport based on collecting objects, solving puzzles based on word puns or lateral thinking and interacting with other characters wandering through the city. The animation is in the same standard as Tir Na Nog, although there is no parallax scrolling. Since the game can take many hours to complete, there is support for saving its state to cassette tape.

Dun Darach improves over its predecessor in that other characters can give short hints to the player, rob him, and confiscate his belongings if he carries stolen goods. The player can also now buy, steal and sell goods from the many shops in the city, bet at a casino (Iomain Ludum) and even deposit money at a bank with daily compound interest. The city of Dun Darach is large and consists of different quarters with shops and the current time of the day is indicated by torches in the wall and by the greetings of characters. There is a "blank" area in the centre of the city in Iomain, the pleasure quarter; this was originally intended to be a brothel called "Lady Q's" and would have opened into a whole red-light district (this was censored and all that remains is a sign saying "Forbidden"). Cuchulainn can move north, south, east and west with the player "rotating" the view using the keyboard and then having Cuchulainn move left or right on the screen, so only one side of the street is visible at once.

Source: Wikipedia, "Dun Darach," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

120936.name: Time For Epic: Heroes in Time! TD Temple Defense
120936.description:
User Summary

Time for Epic! Is a Castle Defense game. Your goal is to protect the Time Portal from 10 different enemies. The game features gorgeous hand-drawn graphics

120937.name: UFOlocaust
120937.description:
"Earth is being invaded and you’re our last hope! An alien race threatens to conquer the only inhabited planet in our solar system. You will be at the helm of our last line of defense, an arsenal created many years ago in order to contain an invisible threat that most thought would never come to pass.

Keep the alien spacecraft from abducting the last surviving citizens of Earth, destroy the aliens, and save the planet.

This arcade game blends the gameplay of Tower Defense with the classic Space Invaders and will provide you with hours of endless fun.

High-definition graphics for iPhone 4 iPad 2
25 incredible levels that will take you all around the world
More than 20 different weapons
Over 40 different weapon upgrades
More than 20 different enemy types
Excellent soundtrack and sound effects
Set of achievements all compatible with Game Center"

Source: The Developer Website.

120938.name: Marsport
120938.description:
Marsport is a science fiction computer game that was released for the ZX Spectrum and Amstrad CPC home computers in 1985. It was published by Gargoyle Games in the United Kingdom and Dro Soft in Spain.

Marsport was intended to be the first part of a trilogy called "The Siege of Earth" but parts two and three (Fornax and Gath) were not forthcoming. Because of this, it is often regarded as being part of an unofficial trilogy alongside Tir Na Nog and Dun Darach (both of which are part of the same official series) due to its having very similar gameplay to these titles. Marsport also has similarities to the later Gargoyle game, Heavy on the Magick.

The year is 2494. For seventy years, the Earth has been under siege by the insectoid Sept. Since the siege began, the Sept have been kept at bay by a huge Force Sphere which surrounds the Earth and the Moon. However, the Sept are on the verge of discovering how to breach the Sphere unless it can be strengthened according to the formulae contained in the original plans. Unfortunately, these plans are concealed somewhere in the Martian city of Marsport, now Sept-occupied and booby-trapped by the city's M-Central computer. One man, Commander John Marsh, has been sent to retrieve the plans in the belief that a determined man can sometimes achieve more than an army.

Marsport effectively has three distinct objectives: 1) Locate the M-Central computer; Marsport is a three-dimensional city, where levels are connected by express tube, which will take you up or down, but probably not both. In addition, many sections of the city cannot be reached until specific problems have been solved. 2) Gain access to the original Sphere plans, held in M-Central's inner sanctum. This will require re-exploration of Marsport, for having achieved the first objective, you will find that many parts of the city, previously unreachable, will now be open to you. 3) Leave the city of Marsport with the plans intact, which may prove the hardest task of all...

Source: Wikipedia, "Marsport," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

120939.name: Mystery Manor: Hidden Adventure
120939.description:
"A dreadful Event took place in the Manor and completely ruined the ordinary life of its inhabitants. Their deeply loved master Mister X has suddenly disappeared leaving nothing but a strange message. Only you can break the secret of the Mystery Manor. Jump into the crazy hidden objects action!"

Source: The Developer Website.

120940.name: Pilgrim
120940.description:
Experience the struggle between good and evil represented in John Bunyan’s classic Christian story “The Pilgrim’s Progress”.

"The Pilgrim's Progress" book by John Bunyan is a metaphor for the Christian's journey to heaven and his battle against the enemies of his salvation. He is also weighed down by a great burden, so unbearable that Christian must seek deliverance. Narrated in the form of an allegory it records his dangerous journey and safe arrival at his desired country. In this game, the player(s) represent the pilgrims as they travel through the perilous land on their way to Celestial City.

OBJECT OF THE GAME
The player(s) must leave Destruction and make it safely to the Celestial City. In their way, they must overcome many obstacles that test their faith in a territory full of enemies and danger.

COMPONENTS
- Player board
- 20 location tiles
- 25 location tokens
- 10mm cubes markers
Cards:
- 51 Companion
- 10 Valley of the Shadow of Death
- 1 Divine Intervention

120941.name: Windgeflüster (Issue 33 - Jun 1996)
120941.description: This issue contains the universal adventure "Der Zauberwald" and an interview with Ed Greenwood.

120942.name: Silent Hill HD Collection
120942.description:
User Summary

Re-mastered to HD at 720p for improved graphics on PlayStation 3, both the critically acclaimed Silent Hill 2 & 3 with full PlayStation Network trophy support. New in-game voiceovers directed by series vocalist Mary Elizabeth McGlynn and soundtrack score enhancing the storytelling and ambient music.

The PS3 HD Collection release removed most of the iconic fog that helped to hide the featureless environments in the original PS2 release. Several bugs, glitches, missing textures, and other problems not in the original were present in the HD Collection. A patch is available to download to fix the game.

120943.name: Reaper Madness
120943.description:
From Introduction:

Hey now, sparky, you don’t wanna go over there. It ain’t pretty, and seein’ your own mangled corpse sure as heck ain’t gonna improve your day one bit. Good thing old Sam plucked you when he did; that woulda hurt like the dickens. Hi, I’m Jimbo, and I’m your new boss! What’s that? No, you don’t really have that job anymore, or at least you won’t when your boss finds out about your unfortunate accident. In case the whole “mangled corpse” thing didn’t give it away, you’re dead. Well, not really dead, but you’re not alive anymore. Some folks call it being ‘undead,’ but that kinda talk gives me the heebiegeebies. Anyway, since Sam’s moved on to bigger and better things, you’re his replacement. Some people try to candy coat what we do and call themselves “terminal episode guidance specialists” or some such nonsense, but that’s just a buncha two-dollar words. You’re a Grim Reaper now, ace!
Welcome aboard!

120944.name: DausendDodeDrolle (Issue 24 - Oct 2011)
120944.description: This issue contains the settings "Der Seelenwald von Ferûn Manlach" and "Der Palast von Nikostria" and an article about the combat system of Midgard

120945.name: Crusade of Kings
120945.description:
All the splendor, majesty, Byzantine plotting, and senseless destruction of the first three Crusades, designed for the Wildside Gaming System (but easily adapted to other systems). Contains all the resources a GM needs to build a Crusades-based campaign, whether the players are in the roles of princes or peasants, Crusaders or Caliphs.

Nearly a century of history is covered, allowing for long campaigns, and the book spills over into a variety of environments in Europe and the Middle East. Want to run a Byzantine campaign? an adventure centered on a mountain fortress in Lebanon? It’s all here: everything you need to know to live or die in world-spanning adventures from 1094-1192.

Crusade of Kings is filled with information on key environments (How did people dress in Antioch? What’s a really bad day to be caught in Jerusalem?) and with profiles of major players in the first three Crusades, including larger-than-life figures like Richard the Lion Hearted and Saladin. It has exactly the information you need to run a Crusades-based campaign without getting bogged down. There are also dozens of adventure seeds for GMs who want to get started in a hurry.

-- Publisher's website, http://www.wildsidegame.net/bk_crusade.asp

120946.name: Push
120946.description:
Push is played on a 15X15 square board with each player having 10 stones. Pieces move one as a chess king, and a player has three moves on a turn.

There must always be a one place buffer between opposing pieces. When a piece is moved next to an opponent piece it is pushed away one space to create the buffer. If a piece is pushed into another piece, or the side, it is captured. A player loses when they are down to one piece.

Push was an entry in the THE THOUSAND-YEAR GAME DESIGN CHALLENGE

120947.name: Stuff
120947.description:
From publisher blurb:

Didn't read the manual for that new toy, didja?
Lucky for you, we've compiled QAGS STUFF, a new equipment guide full of toys and exapmles of how to use them.

This book features listings for:

Jet Boots
Pocket Computer
Personal Force Fields
Anti-Ship Missiles
the dreaded Cathedralpult




Whether you're playing in a fantasy, horror, modern-day, or science fiction game, QAGS Stuff has everything you need. It's chock-fulla the damnedest things, from pointy sticks and armour to time machines and the mighty Cathedralpult. Stuff is fun to read and the equipment inside can be easily adapted to any game system.

120948.name: Tesla: Master of Lightning
120948.description:
A VERY High-Voltage Card Game for 2 to 6 players.

Through clever play of your cards, you place bids, hoping to win tricks which will bring you more powerful cards to use in future hands. So it's a blind-bidding, trick-taking, deck-building hybrid.

The 144 cards in the deck depict events in the amazing life of the great electrical genius, Nikola Tesla, one of the inventors of our modern age. Following the successes and pitfalls of his life story, each player in this game attempts to accumulate the greatest amount of Voltage (victory points) before the deck runs too low.

In keeping with the theme, many aspects of the game are in threes, and victory points are measure in Millions of Volts (A.C., of course).

Each player begins with an "Input Deck" of nine cards. From this they deal themselves a hand of six to play the round. Each round then consists of three tricks. The first trick consists of (A) drawing three "prize cards" from the main deck that the players will try to win and (B) each player chooses three cards from their hand to bid, trying to win those cards. (Sometimes, if the "prize" is undesirable, a player may play low to intentionally lose the trick.) The winner gets the prize cards, and all players keep the cards they played, which go into their "Output Deck" (discard) for future use.

The second trick in the round uses TWO prize cards and each player plays TWO cards from their hand to the trick. Finally the last trick is a One-Card trick. And again, prize cards go to the player's own Output Deck, and all other cards are recycled by each player.

In succeeding rounds, when a player's Input Deck is depleted, their Output Deck is shuffled and placed face-down to become the new supply for their hand. This way, the prize cards come into play as the game progresses. Some cards are "Power Cards" which cause extra draws, discards, and actions to be taken which add extra value to one's hand, and can hinder an opponent's efforts.

The winning is determined after all cards have been won. Some cards are "Positive" and some "Negative" scoring cards, and several have special point values. The suited cards do not have a scoring value UNLESS the player has acquired a "Value for your Voltage" card, which gives those cards points at the end. Therefore, gaining those during the game (even though they have no value until the end) can make the difference in a winning or losing score.

Now available at Amazon.com and RedHenToys.com !

120949.name: Antipode
120949.description:
Antipode is played on a 5-hexagon, with elements of Hex, Othello, Yinsh

On a turn a player places a token of his color, flipping any adjacent tokens (ala Othello).

And the second step of your turn is to move your pawn. You may move your pawn any number of spaces in a straight line, making no turns in the process.

Your pawn must come to rest on a token of your own color. You may not land on an empty space, or one of your opponent’s tokens. While you are allowed to pass over as many tokens and empty spaces as you wish, you may not, under any circumstances, pass over your opponent’s pawn. Passing over tokens causes them to be flip.

The game ends when one player successfully makes a connection from any one corner to that corner’s exact opposite (Hex-like). The connection will cover a minimum of nine spaces, but the connection does not need to form a straight line.

120950.description:
This Expansion adds 200 new and updated unit data sheets (on CD-ROM) for NWS "Modern Naval Conflicts: 1970s" game to cover the USSR, UK, and USA for the 1980s period, as well as adding unit data for Argentina and UK for the 1982 Falklands Conflict. The Expansion also includes two new thick paper gloss map panels (each 11" x 17") that cover the Falkland Islands and Argentine coastal areas so that you can create and/or play scenarios that can range over the entire Falklands theater.
The Expansion includes a 20 page Rules Manual that has two sections: the First section adds new, expanded and advanced rules for MNC that add new depths of realism to the game, as well as accounts for advances in technology that occurred during the 1980s time frame. The Second section of the manual covers the 1982 Falklands Conflict, with geographical and related information (as well as rules specific to the Falklands Conflict) needed to plan, create, and play scenarios for the Conflict. This section also contains information about different types of missions that each side performed during the Conflict to help players create their own scenarios. Each mission type also includes a historic 'starter scenario' that demonstrates a typical version of that mission.

The Expansion also includes a new sheet of 280 die-cut counters, with new counters for missiles for red and blue sides, and adds sufficient counters to add a third side (green) to play, which can be used for the Argentine side in Falkland scenarios, or perhaps as a minor navy in a GIUK battle.

Website: http://www.navalwarfare.net/mnc.html
120950.name: Modern Naval Conflicts: GIUK 1980s Expansion / Falklands Conflict

120951.name: Rush Run Riot
120951.description:
Rush Run Riot is played in an 8X8 board.

Each player has a king (unmoveable) set in opposite corners.

Players also have 4 pawns which can move as rook up to 3 spaces. Players move two pawns per time.

A pawn may jump a pawn of its own color.

There are also four neutral 'bouncers' which are shared. They move as a chess king (and are moved in lieu of a pawn move.

Players must move their pawns across the board and surround the opponent's king.

It was an entry in the Thousand-Year Game Design Challenge.

120952.name: Mucha Lucha! Mascaritas of the Lost Code

videogameversion.155368: North American Game Boy Advance edition

120952.description:
From the North American GBA Box Back

It's Lucha Time!

Someone stole the all important Code of Masked Wrestling from the school of Lucha, and as any true luchador knows - that's a big problema. Now it's up to the three mascaritas to recover the book pronto and save the world of masked wrestling - or be thrown out of school!

Be The Greatest Masked Wrestler of All Time - 15 moves, including the Pulverizving Pinball and the Buena Bulldozer of Truth!

All For One - Play as all three mascaritas - Buena Girl, Rikochet, and the Flea!

Lucharaaaan! - Take on four mad bosses, such as Potato Patata Jr., and Cindy Slam!

120953.name: Murchad's Legacy
120953.description:
From publisher blurb:

They say it's good to be the king.
Tell that to King Almagaid of Launhym.

Tattooed orcs invading from the north, dwarves in the neighboring mountains lamenting their failed “gunpowder” weapons, a vast empire to the south, wealthy elitists taking control from the east, druids and clerics fighting internally, barons threatening to tear the country up, your wife of over twenty years may just well be having an affair, and all because some wizard named Murchad didn't get his way.

Murchad's Legacy is a campaign setting in the "knights and castles" tradition using the d20 ruleset where the story slowly advances with every level up and the players drive the plot.

Its time to save a kingdom!

120954.name: The Gathering
120954.description:
From publisher blurb:

Lost on hostile ground with only strangers for company, the life you knew slipped away during the night. Your one hope lies in cooperation, if you don't kill each other first. With Fate's blessing, you might live long enough to find a way back to the world you knew.

The first in NRP's Special Edition series, The Gathering is designed to bring together a new group of characters or be easily inserted into an existing campaign. This module includes a complete low-level adventure site, details for adaptation, and stat blocks where you need them most. Also included is the information necessary to access The Gathering support site where you will be able to download free supplements and bonus material including Eddings Cross.

120955.name: Plasmatron
120955.description:
User Summary

Plasmatron is a side-scrolling budget shooter. Captain Ford's is sent on a recon mission on Loughton 2. On the way, he must fight wave after wave of enemy spacecrafts.

120956.name: Fantasy Fiends: Kobolds
120956.description:
From publisher blurb:

Are your kobold encounters stale and tired. Does your carefully planned encounter abruptly end when the party casts sleep and fireball? Aren't kobolds supposed to be tricky and dangerous?

Do you want to scare the pants off of an 8th level party with .... KOBOLDS?!!!

Good News! Fantasy Fiends: Kobolds is here to help.
Within this product you will find:

6 unique kobold types that work together in battle.
Brief background into kobold ecology.
Detailed battle tactics for each kobold type.
Common kobold traps.
Sample Encounter Groups from Encounter Level 1 to 8
Unique Combat Focus Sheets for each kobold. No more searching through lots of books for a particular spell or feat.
Full color 1 inch tokens for battlemap play.
Designed to be used in 15 minutes or less!

120957.name: SORD: System Operational Reference Digest
120957.description:
From publisher blurb:

Are you tired of...

Players searching through books at the height of your encounter, just to Demoralize an enemy.
Determining the AC mods of a character Fighting Defensively?
Figuring out the Armor Check Penalty of a Heavily Encumbered Chainmail-wearing elf trying to jump across a 10-foot chasm?
Searching for all the details of one rule across four or five pages spread all over the place in your handbook..
Spending 45 minutes running a 4 round combat encounter.




Then SORD is for you!
Whether you are a player or gamemaster, SORD puts the rules in their place - Literally!

All the attack types are found on a single page, from Attacks of Opportunity to Coup de Grace.
Need a Banded Mail's Armor Check penalty because your hero is climbing a rope? It's on the armor class page with all the other important Armor Class modifiers.
And so much more! Skills, Special Attacks, Damage, Weapons... it's in SORD.

Did you notice all the examples mention a Single PAGE!? That's right, SORD has a 1-page design. For each major component, AC, Attacks, Damage, you name it, the rules are contained on a single page!

With SORD:

Combat will speed up by 10-15 minutes per encounter..
Character generation is a snap.
Players will try riskier, more amazing combat actions.
Your game will be more fun, because you will spend more time playing!

120958.name: Trouble in Tallreed Waters
120958.description:
From publisher blurb:

The tiny town of Tallreed Waters seems idyllic enough, but evil encroaches from the forest and hills surrounding it. The players arrive in the town searching for clues regarding a lost package and uncover more than than they expect. Now, they are in a fight to save not only themselves, but the residents as well. Do the heroes have the mettle - and the luck - to win the day?

A complete adventure for a party of characters of 1st level. It features:

Two large battlemaps at 275 dpi color (18' x 27' and 24' x 27')
Four pregenerated characters
Fold up miniatures
Six encounters of varying styles and tactical situations
Quick Setup - Everything you need to start playing in about an hour!
Numerous adventure hooks and more!

120960.name: House Calls
120960.description:
Designer Blurb:

I need 20 ccs of everything. Stat.

It’s not so much the case load, the overdoses, and the severe lack of disrespect that walks into this hospital everyday that makes me want to take a bottle of pills to each and every inbred patient here at Mercy General. And it's not so much that health care is a joke, a whole lot of guess work, and the antibiotics du jour that drive most of us to binge drinking, sleeping around, and moonlighting. It's not the free clinic days, the group sessions, and the unending paperwork that convinced me that being a doctor isn't really want I want anymore. It’s not even the way this place is organized with the mirco-managed precision of a Chinese-Italian fire brigade.

What it really comes down to is this: with $250,000 in student loans, what else am I going to do?

120961.name: Dollar Bill Poker
120961.description:
Dollar Bill Poker - An inset on the box lid shows Tony Randall and Jack Klugman endorsing the game.

Dollar Bill Poker (a game of bluff and challenge) is similar to "Liar's Dice" using a special deck of numbered cards instead of dice. There are six cards of each number 1 through 6 and six "Wild Cards". Everyone (from two to six players) starts with a handful of dime-sized cardboard discs, each of their own color. A special green playing mat is placed in the center of the playing area. It contains places for cards and a grid for the betting discs. The dealer deals out a predetermined number of cards depending on the number of players, and each player lays three cards in the "Down" space in front of him on the game mat.

The first player will add a card to their "Down" stack and place a bid of at least two of any number one through six by putting a disc on the grid in the proper row and column to indicate their bid. In turn around the board, each player must make a higher bid or challenge the bid just made. The bids reflect the combined total number of cards in everyone's "Down" stack having the same number on the card as the bid (including "Wild Cards"). For example: a bid of 4 fives, means that a player thinks there are at least 4 cards containing the number five (or "wild") in the collective total of everyone's "Down" stack. Players may bluff in their bidding in an effort to outwit the other players.

When a challenge occurs, the other players (in turn) get to place a higher bid or allow the challenging player go through with the challenge. If no higher bids are placed, the cards from everyone's "Down" stack are revealed to see if the bid was successful or not. Standard poker chips are used to keep score. The winner is the player with the most chips after the predetermined number of rounds have been played or some other end-game condition occurs. (The rules are inconclusive on how to end the game, but a predetermined number of rounds seems to be the direction intended by the game designers.)

120962.name: Mulan Matchin' Fashion Puzzle Game
120962.description:
Game contains 4 pagodas and 16 puzzle pieces, along with a spinner. To start, all puzzle pieces are placed face down in the center and each player takes one pagoda.

On each turn, the player spins the spinner. If it lands on black, you turn over a black piece from the pile. If it lands on white, you turn over a white piece from the pile. If the upturned piece matches the player's pagoda color, they keep it. If not, it is shown to all players and returned to the center, white or black side up. If the spinner lands on Mushu, the player must trade their pagoda with another player. First player to complete their pagoda with all 4 pieces wins.

120963.description:
Translated from the French rulebook:
You don't know? It seems that our dear Paladin has received a fantastic proposal. He is on tour with a series of conferences entitled "My Struggles Against Evil". It is so famous, he was offered a caravan of luxury and in an interview with the magazine "Adventures, Adventurers", he confessed he did not intend to resume his original post.
Good news for you, right?
Well actually ... not really. It's complicated getting rid of the righteous. As soon as the tent of the former paladin was deserted, not one, but two of his colleagues took up residence: a slender elf and a robust dwarf (sigh). Beware this rather incongruous duet ... their mind is as twisted as that of their predecessor and they seem equally determined to fight Evil (sigh ...).

This mini extension allows you to replace the two original paladins with two pairs of new paladins. Leave the original Paladin in the box and place the elf and dwarf pair on the tent at the start of each year. The first person to cross the paladin line on the evilometer will get the elf. If another player crosses the line, the less evil of the two will get the elf, and the other will get the more difficult dwarf.

The elf is only worth 4 points at the end of the game while the dwarf is worth 6.
120963.name: Dungeon Lords: The New Paladins

120965.description:
Game description from the publisher:

The Deathwing Space Marine Pack, a Print on Demand expansion for Space Hulk: Death Angel - The Card Game, includes an alternate set of Space Marines to replace the ones from the Death Angel base game.

By simply switching out a number of your base game combat teams, you can bring new strategic options to your fight against the vile Genestealers. In addition to bringing new abilities such as Hellfire and Trail of Destruction, the Deathwing Space Marines offer an expanded use for the support tokens found in the base game. From an Apothecary that can use his Support Tokens to assist his wounded brothers, to the relentless Interrogator-Chaplain who is able to give a fellow Space Marine any Support Token he spends, the Deathwings make optimal use of the Support action.
120965.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel – The Card Game – Deathwing Space Marine Pack

71721.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel – The Card Game

120967.name: Beleman (Issue 6 - Mar 2006)
120967.description:
This issue contains the 4 ingame regional isues:


Havena Fanfare
Andergastische Freie Trommel
Nostrische Postille
Thorwal-Standarte


all with editiorial Gamemaster tricks and tips for regional scenarios and background infos.

120968.name: Outbreak: Wild Kingdom
120968.description:
publisher blurb

A new supplement for the Zombie Survival RPG "Outbreak: Undead", Wild Kingdom showcases the wilder side of the zombie apocalypse. With a focus on wilderness survival, one can't ignore the question "What if it was the animals there were infected? Not us?" Now is your chance to find out!

Wild Kingdom includes:
- An expanded Bestiary with in-depth guides for using and creating your own zombie beasts!
- New Character Types
- New Skills
- New Equipment
- New Strongholds and Stronghold Upgrades
- New Missions
- Expanded environment rules
- Detailed sample campaign that if you survive will leave you saying "Don't go to the Fair King Zoo!"

120969.name: Beleman (Issue 7 - Sep 2006)
120969.description:
This issue contains the 4 ingame regional isues:


Havena Fanfare
Andergastische Freie Trommel
Nostrische Postille
Thorwal-Standarte


all with editiorial Gamemaster tricks and tips for regional scenarios and background infos.

120970.name: Beleman (Issue 8 - Feb 2008)
120970.description:
This issue contains the 4 ingame regional isues:


Havena Fanfare
Andergastische Freie Trommel
Nostrische Postille
Thorwal-Standarte


all with editiorial Gamemaster tricks and tips for regional scenarios and background infos.

120971.name: Beleman (Issue 9 - Oct 2010)
120971.description:
This is the last issue, contains only the 2 ingame regional isues:


Nostrische Postille
Thorwal-Standarte


also with editiorial Gamemaster tricks and tips for regional scenarios and background infos.

the Havena Fanfare continues as own fanzine.

120972.name: Ça m'intéresse
120972.description:
Truo or False? 2000 unusual and surprising assertions await you in four areas and interesting news: science and technology, environment, health and curiosity.
Players must reach the boxes "Quiz" to be able to answer questions and win the corresponding rings. The first to win all 4 different "Quiz"-categories is the winner.

120973.name: Whirligig
120973.description:
Party game for children. 12 cards with different photographs are placed where every participant can see them. They get a sheet to record their answers on. Each picture will have in it at least 4 items beginning with a letter of the alphabet. Picture 1 might be letter D, Picture 2 might be letter A, and so on.

The child with the most correct answers, wins.

It was selected as a favourite game by the BBC's Children's Hour programme.

120974.name: Chiens et Chats du monde
120974.description:
A set of travel and hunting dogs and cats must walk around the board (in the opposite direction, to join their boxes with their pictures. Tokens are moved by rolling the dice. A little dog chasing a cat (or vice versa) arrived exactly on his square. The first player to put all his chips into the opponent's side triggers scoring.
10 points is earned for a chip on his arrival box, for a token in the opponent's camp, -5 is earned for a token that has not moved.

Contents:

A plateau with 148 boxes
24 dogs and 24 cats chips
48 action cards representing tokens
An explanatory booklet on the 48 dogs and cats.

120975.name: Write the Word "Cricket"
120975.description: Party game. Each guest is given a card with questions on it. The twist is that each answer will be a word related to the game of cricket. For example, 'Imposed by a judge' would be 'bail'. There are 12 answers in all. The most correct answers, wins

120976.name: Party Medley
120976.description:
Party game. There are card slips (like tickets in size). One slip will have a word on it. Its matching slip will have another word but related to the first slip word. For example, a first-half slip might have the word 'Buckingham' and its other half would be the word 'Palace'.

The second half slips are placed around the house. Each player is given a first half slip with the word that will match one of the slips around the house. At the word "Go", the players set off to look for their match. If a player thinks he has found it, he takes both slips back to the host and, if correct, earns one point. Then he is given another slip to solve. After the host calls time, the player with the most points, wins.

120977.name: Underwood
120977.description:
The game “Underwood” reminds you of a simple card game based on its game mechanic but the actual point of it is to form words using letters, sort of like “Scrabble”. “Underwood” has a much more “intellectual-educational tint” compared to normal card games and a much more dynamic gameplay than “Scrabble”: words are easier to form, there are more unexpected events in the game and a lot less stress.

At the beginning of the game each player receives 7 cards. The deck is placed on the table, one card is drawn and placed next to it, this will be the beginning of the “tape”. Players then take turns.

A players turn consist of:
• Draw three cards from the deck,
• If possible form a word using the cards from your hand and placing it before you,
• Place one of his remaining cards to the “tape”.

Each player during his turn adds one card to the “tape”, this way the “tape” becomes longer. If a player needs a certain letter to form a word but doesn’t have them he can take them from the “tape”, he also takes the remaining letters following the one he took.

The “Underwood” card — a free card. Can replace any letter in played word. You can take the “Underwood” card used by another player by replacing it with the letter it was used as. “Underwood” cannot be placed on the “tape”.

Prize cards can be played together with a word if the word fits the cards criteria (for example, is a piece of clothing, none of the letters repeat). The prize card increases the points for that word and can give a player some extra possibilities.

When a player “leaves” (has no cards left to play at the end of his turn or only has prize cards), the round ends and points are counted. Points for a players word are calculated based on the letter cost of that word (each letter is worth a certain amount of points) and prize card used. The cost of letters that remain on the players hands is deducted from his point total. It is possible to get a negative result due to this.

Points earned during a round sum up with points gained on previous rounds. The game is played until one player earns the necessary amount of points to win (the amount of points should be decided before starting the game). The first one to earn them is the winner.

This game contains:
• 102 letter-cards;
• 14 prize cards;
• 4 “Underwood” cards;
• Game rules.

More about cards
A letter card, apart from the letter also has its cost shown (how points a player gains from using it in his word) and the number of cards in the deck with this letter.

A prize card has: an icon, conditions to play this card and the prize that it gives. The icon shows what the card requirements are. There is also a more detailed explanation on what needs to be done.

120979.name: Pictolingua
120979.description:
From publisher's website

A vocabulary-learning game featuring the colorful illustrations of Swiss artist Karen Ichters. This game has 50 flashcards, 10 playing boards and 125 tokens to let you learn 50 words in 5 languages (the 4 languages of Switzerland plus English). Practice your language skills by trying to associate images with words. Young children can play an easier version using boards that already pair images with words. Older children and adults can play a more challenging guessing game using image-only boards. The first and lucky one to guess five successive images on the board shouts "Lingua" and wins!

120980.name: Guessing Sketches
120980.description:
Party game. 12 cards are placed around the house, each card having a cryptic clue to a subject sketched on it.

Example: a phrase;
An M in the top left corner
A T in the top right corner
A rabbit's head in the middle
An E in the bottom left corner
A D in the bottom right corner
Answer = Empty Headed (MT Head ED)

The player who gets the most right, wins.

120981.name: Reanimation: A Zombie Survival Game
120981.description:
The city of Whitewater has suffered a great tragedy; for reasons unknown the dead have risen up from their graves and seek to feed upon the living. The city became overrun in a single night and the few remaining survivors now scavenge to survive during the day and barricade themselves safely away at night.

Players take control of a small group of three survivors who have managed to last the first few days of infection and even barricade a small building to hunker down for the night in. During the day you will send out two teams to scavenge for weapons, materials to build defenses with, supplies and even other survivors in order to prepare for the night; when 'they' come.

However, things would be easier if other groups of scavengers were not also competing for the same resources as you!

120982.name: Beleman (Issue 0 - Oct 2003)
120982.description:
This special print was the first free introducing issue called Issue Zero and it contains the 4 ingame regional isues:


Havena Fanfare
Andergastische Freie Trommel
Nostrische Postille
Thorwal-Standarte


all with editiorial Gamemaster tricks and tips for regional scenarios and background infos.

120983.name: Beleman (Issue 2.5 - Nov 2004)
120983.description:
This special issue for the Con Ludwigstein contains samples of the 4 ingame regional isues:


Havena Fanfare
Andergastische Freie Trommel
Nostrische Postille
Thorwal-Standarte


all with editiorial Gamemaster tricks and tips for regional scenarios and background infos.

120984.name: Ninja Scooter Simulator
120984.description:
User Summary

A budget clone of the game Metrocross: the player must guide the character to the end of each of the 16 side-scrolling levels before the timer runs out, while dodging obstacles and other vehicles. The player can collect power-ups (more time, more speed) and use scenery elements like ramps to jump over obstacles.

120985.name: The Lost
120985.description:
From Introduction:

This module is designed for 4-5 characters of the 1st level of experience. Although this adventure is set in the world of Citadel , it is loosely written, and can be easily modified to fit into a number of other campaign worlds as well. The story takes place amidst the gloom of a fetid swamp, deep in the Hurad Wilderness, where a temple of Keltahs (god of the sun and strength) lies forgotten and undisturbed, hiding a hideous and terrible secret. Classes such as the Ranger and the Druid will have their chance to shine in the wilderness of the swamp, while other classes, such as the Fighter and the Cleric will prove their valor in the depths of the ruined temple.

120986.name: Reflex
120986.description:
User Summary

Reflex is a budget Breakout clone, with the usual features of the genre: tens of levels, power-ups (laser, longer bat, faster ball and others), monsters interfering with the ball...

Developer: Kevin Ayre

120987.name: Mega Bloks Domino Build
120987.description:
This Mega Bloks Dominoes Build game challenges players to match cards with colors and animals to win block pieces. The first player to collect all four animal block pieces and build their zoo friend wins.

Oversized blocks and cards are perfect for little hands.
Details:
Includes: 30 cards & 16 Mega Bloks
Ages 3 years & up
For 2 to 4 players

(website)

120988.name: Rollespilsmagasinet Fønix  (Issue 19 - October 1997)
120988.description:
From the front page:

Rollespilsmagasinet Fønix
Danmarks eneste magasin om Rollespil, Brætspil, Live og Kortspil
Cyberpunk
Vampire
Morten Koch

Cover by Palle Schmidt

120989.name: Citizen News
120989.description:
The object is to become the richest player or own a majority of 15 shares in at least three of the 10 newspapers in the game.

In his turn player choose one of a following action:

Buys or sells shares to other players
Buys shares in the bank to their value, that each log is represented by 15 shares increasing in value 10 000 (pr 1) 150 000 (for 15 °).
Take tokens '+' & '-' depending on the number of shares it has. These chips will raise or lower profits of newspapers
Place each token on a security that one has




and additionally player simultainously reveal the chips and adjusted earnings per share. Then each gets its profits or pays its losses.

It is repeated until one player reaches the goal.

120990.description:
This is a six card promo set. Each card is an event that is thematically tied to one of the six animal classes represented in the base game. These cards can simply be shuffled in with the those of the base game at the start of play to add a bit of variety to the play experience.

The Promo Card Set includes 6 playable cards:
• Apex Predator
• Intelligence
• Migration
• Poisonous
• Semi-Aquatic
• Speciation

(The promo set also includes a seventh "card" which is not intended for play, only for reference: it contains card clarifications and directions for use.)

boardgameversion.155542: Dominant Species: The Card Game (BGG Promo Card Set)

120990.name: Dominant Species: The Card Game – Promo Card Set

120991.name: Devil's Deal
120991.description:
From the introduction to the adventure:

“Devil’s Deal” is an AD&D® adventure intended for use with the Warriors of Heaven accessory [TSR #11361]. The adventure is designed for 4–6 good-aligned celestial PCs of levels 3–4. Celestial races include agathi- non, aasimar, archons, asuras, eladrins, guardinals, and quesar. Archon PCs may be lantern or hound archons only. Ideally, the adventuring party should contain a mixture of lawful, chaotic, and neutral PCs.
Rules for creating aasimon, archon, asuras, eladrin, guardinal, and aasimar PCs are pre- sented in the Warriors of Heaven supplement; rules for creating quesar PCs can be down- loaded from the TSR website (www.tsr.com).

120992.name: Chronomancy & the Multiverse
120992.description:
From the introduction to the document:

Chronomancer is a 96-page booklet for TSR's AD&D(R) game that presents, for the first time ever, a school of wizard's magic that allows player characters to travel through Time itself, in almost any campaign world.

This article is an updated and expanded excerpt from the Chronomancer accessory. It describes how these rules for time travel can be merged with any of the major official campaigns for the AD&D game. Many game designers, editors, and creative directors have added their comments to make this material more complete and interesting; to them I give my eternal thanks.

120993.name: Wild West Shooting Gallery
120993.description:
A target shooting game with some humour. Just look at the outlaw target, shooting his own foot.

Here are the complete rules:

WILD WEST SHOOTING GALLERY
Here we have four lawless characters from way out in the Wild West, at present in a gay mood. Little do they know that the Sheriff’s posse is hot on their trail.
Why not join the Sheriff and his men and try your skill at shooting these rascals down?
HOW TO PLAY
Stand the target in the slotted wooden blocks at the sides of the box, then place it at a distance of four to five feet from the players.
Hold gun in your right hand and insert the metal end of the dart into the muzzle, resting rubber head of dart against palm of left hand, press home dart until spring “clicks" into loaded position.
Play can be for a pre-arranged total score, the first player reaching such score being the winner, or for a certain number of rounds, the highest scorer being the winner, 2nd and 3rd highest runners-up.

120994.name: Omphalos
120994.description: By placing their tiles and moving tiles opposing players together form a square of 5x5 (2 or 3 players) or 7x7 (4 players). Within this square that moved over the part at the option of poses and movements of tiles, each aims to create rows of his color (an alignment with at least three tiles) and antagonize those of its opponents. But the player who occupies one of the tiles with the center of the square at the end of the game double its alignment points (2 players, it double its strongest alignment).

120995.name: Ποιός Πού Πότε Γιατί?
120995.description:
Ποιός Πού Πότε Γιατί? (Who Where When Why?) contains 3.600 questions with their answers, concerning history, geography, arts, animals/plants, sports and science.
The players roll the dice and move on the board, answer the questions and continue to move as long as they are correct. First to make it to the "exit" wins.


Περιέχει 3.600 ερωτήσεις μαζί με τις απαντήσεις τους γύρω από ιστορία, γεωγραφία, γράμματα και τέχνες, ζώα και φυτά, αθλητισμό, επιστήμες. Οι παίκτες παίζουν πάνω στο ταμπλό, απαντούν σε ερωτήσεις και τσεκάρουν τις απαντήσεις με σκοπό να φτάσουν πρώτοι στην έξοδο.

120996.name: The Trial of Poland
120996.description:
Publisher's summary:

The Trial of Poland is a game that focuses on the rise of the Solidarity movement in Poland n 1980, from the point of view of the established powers confronted by a legitimate and ultimately existential threat. Each of the characters is a historic eastern bloc leader and, in his own way, a terrible person. The game hinges on a single decision—will Poland be invaded?

This is an experimental freeform game.

120997.name: Wise Saws
120997.description:
Party game.

Each guest receives a card with 20 lines from a saying I would think. They have to fill in the second line which must rhyme with the first line. The bizarre example given is;

"You may find, once you've got her for better or worse"
"That ---------------"

Did you get it? Me neither. The actual winning line is;
"That the Grey Mare's the better horse"

Come on Delgado - Worse and Horse do not rhyme!

The guest getting the most right answers, wins.

120998.name: Mindstein
120998.description:
In Mindstein, each player takes a turn as the reader, reading a card with five multiple choice questions. Where Mindstein differs from a run-of-the-mill trivia game is that each multiple choice question has three answers corresponding to three different letters; the correct answers for each question spell a five letter word that players compete to be the first to yell out.

If you get the five letter word first, you get to draw a letter from the draw pile; first to spell "S-M-A-R-T" wins!

120999.name: Komm wir spielen Bauernhof
120999.description:
From the publishers description: Who wouldnt own a really nice farm. With cow and horse, tractor, house and barn etc. Everyone can win these in this game. Guessing and luck with the dice will lead to victory. Who first gets a farm by dice rolls wins.

It is a roll and move game. Twelve cards for each player are shuffled and put on the board. Clockwise the players roll and move their pawns according the die roll. Sometimes they get to take a card, sometimes they must get rid of a card, and sometimes they challenge the other player. Challenging means putting the die in one hand and then the player guesses which hand. Correct guesses give the player a card, false guesses make him lose a card. The first player to have 7 (out of 12 per player) cards has a full farm and wins.

121000.name: Honor + Intrigue

rpghonor.23175: 2011 Indie RPG Award - Best Production - Runner-Up

121000.description:
Publisher blurb:

Honor + Intrigue is a new, standalone game from Basic Action Games. Inspired as much by Hollywood as by history, Honor + Intrigue pays homage to the swashbucklers of the silver screen as well as great works such as those of Dumas and Sabatini. Game Masters should feel free to use history as a source of inspiration, not a restriction. True to its inspiration, Honor + Intrigue plays fast and cinematic, leaving the focus on drama and action unfolding.

120501.name: Six Planar Gates
120501.description:
From publisher blurb:

In this 4-page PDF, Philip Reed presents six new planar gates that can be used in any planar campaign. The Door of Fire, The Infinite Ladder, The Unwanted Coach and three others are described in this short PDF. Suitable for use with any D20 System game involving planar travel.

120502.name: Six Swarms
120502.description:
From publisher blurb:

In this 17-page PDF, Michael Hammes details six new swarm creatures. The oozling swarm, the wizard's doom, the lightning bug swarm -- all of these creatures are fully detailed with D20 System game statistics, origin and reproduction information, details on the swarms' diet and appearance, and where the swarm is most likely located (and under what circumstances a swarm is likely to be encountered).

Hyperlinked and bookmarked PDF. Very easy on your printer. Monster statistics are presented on single pages (except for the wizard's doom which is so large it requires two pages) so that DMs can print just the statistics they need.

120503.name: Six Unexpected Planar Gates
120503.description:
From publisher blurb:

Welcome back, planar travelers. It has been many a moon since last we examined an assortment of planar gates so let us launch right into things with this latest half-dozen gates, Six Unexpected Planar Gates. Within the pages of this 5-page PDF, written by Philip Reed, you will find:

Blood of the Experienced Traveler: We all carry the potential to unlock worlds.
Footsteps in the Breathing Stream: The misery of a race long expired is your gateway to other planes of existence.
Gauntlets of Ebakar Scye: Pray that the gauntlets of this evil general remain undiscovered or you may very well wish for your own death.
Gaze of the Twisted Statue: In the city destroyed stands the key to its living past.
Planar Rains: Suffer the rains and embrace the world of the suffering.
Sixth Cell on the Right: If you are imprisoned, pray that you are not locked within the sixth cell on the right.

120504.name: RAWR!: The Monstrous Adventure Game
120504.description:
From the section called Welcome To RAWR!:

The Land of Monsters is in peril!

From deep in the Land of Dreams, Nightmare sends his minions to collect the Imagination Shards of the Dreamers, the children who no longer believe that monsters are the good guys.

The monsters have had enough. They are tired of being called the bad guys. Being a monster used to be a title of respect and decency. It is time for the monsters to fight back.

RAWR!: The Monstrous Adventure Game is a roleplaying game set in the Land of Monsters, the place where the monsters under your beds and in your closets live. The game allows players to pretend to be one of those monsters as they fight against the dreaded Nightmare to protect the very humans who have turned their backs on monsters.

This is the core rulebook for the RAWR! system.

120505.name: The Assassin's Guide to Poison
120505.description:
From publisher blurb:

This one was hell. It started out as 101 Poisons and Magical Diseases but at about poison #56 I realized I was very unhappy with most of what I had w ritten. I shoved it aside and completed 101 Mundane Treasures and 101 Arcane Spell Components before coming back to poisons. Then I went on a trip. And then I got sick.

I wrote about twenty poisons the week I was sick and then, the next week, I read them over and realized they sucked.

So I deleted them.

And started over.

No matter how much I slam my head against this thing it just doesn’t work the way I want it to. So what I’ve decided to do is just clean the poisons I’m happy with, throw in some previous open game content that would be of help to those using poisons, and release the thing as a free PDF on my site and RPGNow.

So here it is.

120506.name: The Cursed Temple
120506.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Cursed Temple is a short adventure for four 1st-level PCs. This adventure is designed specifically for good-aligned parties with a cleric or paladin. The Cursed Temple can be easily inserted into any campaign with a forrest and evil dieties.

120507.name: Olduvai's Test
120507.description:
From publisher blurb:

A wise and mysterious sage requires that anyone who wishes to seek him out must undergo a test. Rumor has it that those who complete the test are granted an audience with Olduvai while those who fail wind up paying a higher price. Is it worth the struggle to meet the man known as Olduvai? This module is ideal to use as a mid-adventure change of pace or a jumping off point for a much longer campaign.

Olduvai's Test is a short D20 adventure designed for four to six first or second level characters. The module is designed to be played over the course of one or two game sessions.

Party members may be of any class or alignment; but the party will need to use the Search, Disable Device and Open Lock skills. The adventure introduces beginning players to traps and problems they might encounter in later dungeons and provides them an opportunity to use their skills. It can also lead into additional adventures by supplying the party with information or supplies that they may need. Completion of many aspects of the test requires teamwork and cooperation. Trap dangers - such as damage and the difficulty of detecting and disabling traps - can be increased according to party level. The real treasure provided at the end of the scenario is information and materials the adventurers will need in a continuing campaign.

120508.name: Love Forlorn
120508.description:
From publisher blurb:

A wedding with a missing bride, an uncaring father and a suitor who is out for blood make this a great murder mystery adventure. This module is filled with enough action for the most hack and slash players as well as enough common sense puzzling for those who prefer a wittier path. Of course, we can't say too much about it or we will give away the plot. Beautifully written and very well balanced, this module is sure to be one of your favorites.

Love Forlorn is a short adventure designed for a party with a total of 25 levels (group of lvl 5 - 6). Love Forlorn is a stand-alone adventure in the city of Durblin. Durblin can be dropped into any existing world unchanged or reworked to fit any city in your world. This adventure will satisfy any group's craving for romance, mystery and horror.

Encounters are scaled for a party that uses magic weapons, has a priest and a rogue, and whose members' levels add to approximately 25.

120509.description:
(from S&T press website:)

Operations Olympic & Coronet is an update of the Olympic solitaire game first published in S&T along with a second complete game covering the planned follow-up invasion: Operation Coronet.

The Olympic map has been updated to reflect better understanding of the tough and, in places, impassable terrain as well as the potential landing sites.
The Coronet map shows the flat, wide-open Tokyo plain.
The counters have also been updated with new information about the Japanese order of battle, especially their plan to move 36th Army to Kyushu as a counter-invasion force. With that, the Americans face a force intent on breaking through to the beach.

Also added are: naval gunfire, atomic bombs, and even the Soviets (from a MOVES variant). The Japanese doctrine and supply rules have been updated to better reflect their historic plan for an initial counterattack. The kamikaze rules are also updated with further research into their probable effects.

This Special Edition package includes two full-sized (22x34") maps of the two invasion areas and 560 counters. Both games can be played solitaire or two-player.
120509.name: Operations Olympic & Coronet

120510.name: Slam 'n Jam '95
120510.description:
User Summary

Slam 'n Jam '95 is a basketball game from 1995 which was developed and released exclusively on 3DO. The game features all 27 teams then in the NBA, though it does not feature any of the actual players due to licensing issues. The game was perhaps the first 3D basketball game and was known for its quick play which was somewhere in between the realism of titles like NBA Live '95 and the fantasy of NBA jam. There is a season mode which the player can play through or partially simulate on the way to the playoffs and there is also a playoff mode that can be used as a starting point.

120511.name: Legendary Realms:  Player's Handbook
120511.description:
From the RPG description here on RPGGeek:
Welcome to the world of Ehryn. After the fall of the second empire of mankind, the kingdoms of the eastern hemisphere have entered a renaissance. In a world of fantasy science, you can now play a collaborative story with your friends. The Legendary Realms Player's Handbook includes several customizable
modules to create a pen and paper RPG all your own.

Included Modules:

Modifiers - A simple dice + statistics rolling system that also has great depth.
Expertises - Build a custom character with no classes or levels.
Aetherwarping - In a world of science, magic exists as a fearsome reality altering power.
Miracles - The Gods of Ehryn still make their resence known and answer the prayers of heir followers.
Technology - Many of the kingdoms have developed unique weapons that provide offensive ability to the weak.




Now is your chance to join the divided Elfs, quirky Dwarfs, or the myriad of Humans of Ehryn in new age of adventure!

(And an interesting note on the front cover:
Trapped at a table.
Surrounded by nerds.
Low on dice.)

120512.name: Woe to the Living
120512.description:
In Woe to the Living, you are the sinister spectral force that haunts the night and feeds off the terror you create! You lurk in the darkest places, making night-time strollers walk just a little faster and double-bolt their doors. You must carefully cultivate terror and watch those impacted; too much terror and they die of fright becoming useless to you. Too little terror and you starve.

Sweet delicious terror!

Carefully select your prey across four rounds of game-play. The goal is to have the second highest total terror at the end of the game. This is made more difficult by the other players, all vying for that coveted high, but not highest, terror total. Use a sneaky card swapping mechanic to exchange face down cards throughout each round. Correctly gauge your opponents’ motives in order to feed them the cards they don’t want, or take from them the cards you need.

120513.name: La Table Ronde

rpgissuearticle.138636: Le Castel de la butte aux corbeaux

120513.description:
User Summary:

La Table Ronde (the Round Table) was a French Arthurian Legend RPG. It was sold in a box set.

120515.description:
Turn out the lights and try to be the last mammal standing in this survival dice game based on Latin American folklore. Can you survive the night?

In Chupacabra: Survive the Night, which includes 24 glow-in-the-dark dice, each player rolls six dice at the start of the game and uses their rolled Chupacabra to steal other players' chickens, goats, and bulls. One Chupacabra can capture up to two chickens or one goat, and two Chupacabra can capture a bull – but animal packs are immune to Chupacabra so be sure to roll a lot of the same animal! (As if you have the power to control your dice rolls...)

When a player rolls all Chupacabras, he becomes "Chupacabra Loco" and can capture all of one type of another animal from a player.
120515.name: Chupacabra: Survive the Night

120518.name: Quoth the Raven (Issue 14 - Jun 2007)
120518.description:
Quoth the Raven (Issue 14)

Contents:

Races of the Mists Part IV - The Gnomic By David "of the Fraternity" Gibson
An Audience with the King - Statistics, spell tactics, and other secrets of Azalin Rex By HuManBing
Olerick's Colloquial Guides - Part 2: Vineyards of the Core By Jeremy Roby
Anatomy of a Horror Tale - A model for a Horror Tale By Alex "Ail" Miranda
Codex of Darkened Souls - and the Key of Penitent Salvation By John Pruitt
Twisted Races - A New Edge to the Core Races By Wolf Kook
Olerick's Colloquial Guides - Part 1: Weaponsmiths of the Core By Jeremy Roby
Registry of Monsters - Excerpts from the Register By Stanton F. Fink
Boggy Downs - A New Edge to the Core Races By Stephen "ScS" Sutton

120519.name: Quoth the Raven (Issue 15 - 2008)
120519.description:
Quoth the Raven (Issue 15)

Contents:

Cult of the Morninglord - The Light Before the Dawn By Chris Benton aka Eric the Light Bringer
Verbena - Pain and Sorrow in the House of Healing By Marcin Roszkowski
Devil and the Deep Blue Sea - The Kelpie By Nathan of the Fraternity
Shadow and Flame - Dragonborn in Ravenloft By Eleanor Ferron
New Barovia - A Short Story By Steve Flam
Fairhafen - Where the happy ending is yet to come... By Wolfkook
The Hobby's Ghost-Pipes - Piper of Stonedown By Sharon of the Fraternity
The Northwest Train Line - A Bit of Alternate History By Eleanor Ferron
Sideshow Games - A Short Story By Tami Sammons aka Hadis Deadstalker
Sideshow Games - New Performers for the Carnival By Tami Sammons aka Hadis Deadstalker
Sideshow Game - Map and Vardo Layouts By Tami Sammons aka Hadis Deadstalker

120520.name: Quoth the Raven (Issue 16 - Oct 2009)

rpgissuearticle.152067: Atolls in a Sea of Mist

120520.description:
Quoth the Raven (Issue 16)

Contents:

Hidden Places - Dark Corners of Ravenloft By Jack the Reaper
Dark Corners of Ravenloft - A Fraternity Community Contest Compiled by Joël Paquin
Olerick's Colloquial Guides - Part Three: Hospices and Healers By Jeremy Roby
Through The Cellar Door - Secrets of an Artificial Mistway By Sharon Dornhoff
Atolls in a Sea of Mist - Oubliettes of Terror By Stephen "ScS" Sutton
Rites of Decay - Necromatic Rituals for Ravenloft By Andrew "Alhoon" Pavlides
Starbury Valley - A Settlement in Gothic Earth By Stephen "ScS" Sutton
Empire Hospital - A Haunted Hospital in Bleakstone By Stephen "ScS" Sutton

120522.name: Original Edition Delta: Book of War
120522.description: A miniatures game that, on a statistical basis, faithfully replicates the results of combat in the Original RPG on a mass scale (with each figure representing 10 troops or 1 hero).
